_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Farm Product Raw Material Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    MFA Agri Service - Cedar Creek
Location:    2887 County Road 269, Columbia, MO 65202
Contact:     Rick Smith
Phone:    573-474-2111

1. The Facility Policy 

    MFA Incorporated, and the employees of the MFA Agri Service Cedar Creek are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the North Callaway Fire Protection District, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

    The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of liquid and dry fertilizers and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as crop nutrients.  Bulk and packaged pesticides are  handled and stored at this location.  

    The maximum quantity stored at any one time would be 233,629 pounds.  The facility has (1) 30,000-gallon storage tank and (21) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks that are used for product distribution. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a cargo tank containing approximately 50,000 pounds.

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

    The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law, and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

    There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

    The facility has;
    a

. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA
       Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency
       planning and community right-to-know information as
       required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with
       OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency
       planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

    Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.


    11/17/04
